review.title: Tracking Time-Vertex Propagation using Dynamic Graph Wavelets
review.abstract: Graph Signal Processing generalizes classical signal processing to signal or data indexed by the vertices of a weighted graph. So far, the research efforts have been focused on static graph signals. However numerous applications involve graph signals evolving in time, such as spreading or propagation of waves on a network. The analysis of this type of data requires a new set of methods that fully takes into account the time and graph dimensions. We propose a novel class of wavelet frames named Dynamic Graph Wavelets, whose time-vertex evolution follows a dynamic process. We demonstrate that this set of functions can be combined with sparsity based approaches such as compressive sensing to reveal information on the dynamic processes occurring on a graph. Experiments on real seismological data show the efficiency of the technique, allowing to estimate the epicenter of earthquake events recorded by a seismic network.

metadata.title: Tracking Time-Vertex Propagation using Dynamic Graph Wavelets

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 6.06 653v 1 [cs.L G] 21 Jun 2016 1Index Terms - Graph signal processing, time-vertex signal processing, joint Fourier transform, dynamic processes on graphs, wave equationI. INTRODUCTIONComplex signals and high-dimensional datasets developed from a variety of fields of science, as physics, engineering, genetics, molecular biology and many others, can be natural modelling as values on the edges of weighted graphs [1], [2]. Recently, dynamic activity across networks has been the subject of intensive research to develop new models to understand and analyze epidemic propagation [3], rumor spread across social networks [5] or activity on sensor networks. Advances in graph research have resulted in new tools for processing and analyzing time-varying graph and / or signal on the graph, as multi layer graphs and tensor product of graphs.

sections.heading: II. PRELIMINARIES
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Notation
sections.text: In this paper, we will use uppercase and lowercase letters for linear operators (or matrices) M and column vectors v. x denotes the vectorized version of X. Complex conjugates, transpositions, and conjugate transpose are denoted as X, X, and X *. Lowercase letters a denote scalars, and uppercase letters A denote fixed constants. For each symmetric positive definitive matrix M with singular value substitution M = UB * U *, the matrix function f (M) is defined as f (M) = Uf (B) U *, with the scalar function f applied to each diagonal input of B. The Kronecker product between two matrices (or vectors) is denoted as M1 M2, i.e. the cartesian product between matrices (or vectors) is denoted as M1 × M2 = M2 + IM2, where the identity is identical to matrix M2.

sections.heading: B. Graph Signal Processing
sections.text: Consider a diagram G = (V, E, W) of N nodes and E edges, where V indicates the quantity of nodes and E. The weight function W: V · V → R reflects the extent to which two nodes are related to each other. WG is the weight matrix associated with this function. The combinatorial laplac LG = DG − WG, which is associated with the diagram G, is always symmetrically positively semi-defined, therefore it is characterized by a complete set of oral eigenvectors [11] based on the spectral theorem. We call it UG (n,) = u (n). Therefore, the laplac matrix can be decomposed as LG = UGКGU х G, with a set of ormal eigenvectors [11]. Let us let x: V → R be a diagram signal defined on the diagram node whose value is the n-component of the signal хn (n).

sections.heading: III. TIME-VERTEX REPRESENTATION
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Definition
sections.text: The signals evolve over time via the N vertices of graph G. We refer to the cartesian product between time and graph 2 as the time-vertex domain and the X vertex signal. The time-vertex domain can be interpreted as a cartesian product between the generic graph G = (V, E, W) with laplac LG and the ring graph GT (assuming periodic boundary conditions in time) with laplac LT. The common LT is (LT · LG) x = LGX + XLT (1), whereby the second term is obtained using the property of the Kronecker product (M1 M2) x = M2XM 1. sections.heading: B. Joint Time-Vertex Fourier Transform
sections.text: Since the time-vertex representation is derived from the Cartesian product of the two original domains, the common time-vertex-Fourier transformation (JFT) is obtained by applying the GFT to the graph dimension and the DFT along the time dimension [13]: X: X: (, k) = 1: TN: n: 1T − 1: t = 0X: (n: t) u: (n) e − jωk t T, which can be conveniently rewritten in matrix form as follows: X: X: JFT (X) = U: GXUT. (3) The spectral domain helps define the function localization on the graph as in [8].

sections.heading: IV. DYNAMIC GRAPH WAVELETS
sections.text: The DGW differ from the classical wavelengths in that they are not extended versions of an original mother wavelength. In fact, they propagate functions on the graph that evolve over time according to a PDE. We will use the common representation of the signal to characterize spectral relationships between the two domains and solve the PDE in the spectral range to obtain a useful tool for analyzing time-vertex signals that evolve according to this dynamic process. Finally, we will use the nucleus to form the set of DGW. Due to the lack of translation invariance of the graph, the nucleus will always operate in the graph spectral range and be located on the graph by means of the localization operator as in [8]. On the contrary, the time dependence can be defined either in the spectral or in the time range. In this contribution, we will use the time domain for convenience.

sections.heading: A. Heat diffusion on graph
sections.text: Let us first give a basic example of our model: The diffusion of heat on a graph can be considered a simple dynamic process over a network. It is described by the following (discretized) differential equation: X (n, t) − X (n, t − 1) = − sLGX, (4) with initial distributionX (i, 0) = preservation (i). The solution of the closed form is given by X = e − stLGу. Therefore, the heat diffusion core is isK (sLGX, t) = e − sкаt (5), where the parameter s is thermal diffusivity in classical heat diffusion problems and can be interpreted as a scale parameter for multi-scale dynamic graph wave analysis [9]. This equation models the spread of a function on the graph over time. However, in the present work we want to focus on a dispersion process, moving away from a starting point over time.

sections.heading: B. The wave equation on graphs
sections.text: In order to model functions that develop on a graph, we mainly use the PDE, which is associated with the wave equation. Here, the wave equation is defined on the graph and differs as such from the standard equation. This partial differential equation relates the derivative of second order in time to the spatial Laplat operator of a function: (LT IG) x = − α2 (IT LG) x XLT = − α2LGX (6), where α is the propagation velocity parameter. If one assumes a vanishing initial velocity, i.e. the first derivative in the time of the initial distribution equation yields zero, the solution of this PDE can be written with the function calculus as [14]: X (·, t) = K (sLG, t) = Kt (7), where the equation in the initial distribution equation (n) = X (0) and Kt, s = K, is the equation of numbers.

sections.heading: C. General definition
sections.text: In the following, we will generalize the DGW on the basis of any time apex nucleus. The goal is to design a transformation that will help in the detection of a class of dynamic events on graphs based on an initial common distribution Φm, τ (n, t) = [Иm'φ] (n, t) located around the apex m and time τ. The general expression of the DGW Wm, τ, s at the time t and at the apex n can be written as follows: Wm, τ, s (n, t) = [Kt, sΦm, в] (n, t), в t ≥ 0 (11), where, as before, Kt, s = K (sLG, t) is the matrix function K applied to the scaled laplac sLG and parameterized by time t. Depending on the dynamic graph nucleus, the DGW of a wave solution can mix the wave process, a diffusion or a dynamic process.

sections.heading: D. Causal Damped Wave Dynamic Graph Kernel
sections.text: We define the DGW as the solutions of Equation (6) for different α = √ s. In addition, we need two additional properties. First, we want the shaft to be causal, i.e. to have a starting point in time. Second, the wave propagation in many applications is influenced by attenuation over time. Therefore, we introduce a damping term. DGW, which is defined in the graph spectral range, is defined as W is (λ, t) = H (t) e − βt cos (t-arcs (1 − s2)), (12) where H (t) is the heaviside function and e − βt is the dampled decreasing exponential function in time. Secondly, the damping term has two remarkable effects. First, it reduces the importance of the selected boundary conditions in time (e.g. periodic or reflective), since the shaft disappears before it touches it. Secondly, it favours the construction of a frame of DW that we see is involved in: the lower boundary of DW.

sections.heading: VI. APPLICATION
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Earthquake epicenter estimation
sections.text: We show the performance of the DGW on a source localization problem, where a dynamic event develops according to a certain time-space behavior. We analyze waveforms that have been geographically distributed by seismic stations in New Zealand, connected to the GeoNet Network. The graph is constructed by showing the coordinates of available seismic stations and connecting the next nodes. We consider various seismic events whose epicenters have been located in different areas of New Zealand 1. Each waveform consists of 300 seconds that are sampled at 100 Hz, starting a few seconds before the seismic event. Seismic waveforms can be modeled as oscillating attenuated waves. This model is valid if the spatial domain in which the waves spread is a continuous domain or a regular grid [20]. Here, the domain is the network of sensors and we assume that a dampled wave that spreads across this network is a good approximation.

metadata.abstractText: Graph Signal Processing generalizes classical signal processing to signal or data indexed by the vertices of a weighted graph. So far, the research efforts have been focused on static graph signals. However numerous applications involve graph signals evolving in time, such as spreading or propagation of waves on a network. The analysis of this type of data requires a new set of methods that fully takes into account the time and graph dimensions. We propose a novel class of wavelet frames named Dynamic Graph Wavelets, whose time-vertex evolution follows a dynamic process. We demonstrate that this set of functions can be combined with sparsity based approaches such as compressive sensing to reveal information on the dynamic processes occurring on a graph. Experiments on real seismological data show the efficiency of the technique, allowing to estimate the epicenter of earthquake events recorded by a seismic network.
